analytic.title: Optimal risk control and dividend distribution policies. Example of excess-of loss reinsurance for an insurance corporation

div.p: We consider a model of a financial corporation which has to find an optimal policy balancing its risk and expected profits. The example treated in this paper is related to an insurance company with the risk control method known in the industry as excess-of-loss reinsurance. Under this scheme the insurance company divert part of its premium stream to another company in exchange of an obligation to pick up that amount of each claim which exceeds a certain level a. This reduces the risk but it also reduces the potential profit. The objective is to make a dynamic choice of a and find the dividend distribution policy, which maximizes the cumulative expected discounted dividend pay-outs.
We use diffusion approximation for this optimal control problem, where two situations are considered:

(a) The rate of dividend pay-out are unrestricted and in this case mathematically the problem becomes a mixed singular-regular control problem for diffusion processes. Its analytical part is related to a free boundary (Stephan) problem for a linear second order differential equation. The optimal policy prescribes to reinsure using a certain retention level (depending on the reserve) and pay no dividends when the reserve is below some critical level x 1 and to pay out everything that exceeds x 1 . Reinsurance will stop at a level x 0 ≤ x 1 depending on the claim size distribution. (b) The rate of dividend pay-out is bounded by some positive constant M < ∞, in which case the problem becomes a regular control problem. Here the optimal policy is to reinsure at a certain rate and pay no dividends when the reserve is below x 1 and pay out at maximum rate when the reserve exceeds

x 1 . In this case reinsurance may or may not stop depending on the claim size distribution and the size of M , but in all cases the retention level will remain constant when the reserve exceeds x 1 .

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The problem of optimal dynamic risk control/dividends distribution of a financial corporation has recently gained a lot of attention in Mathematical Finance. In the first papers such as Jeanblanc-Pique and Shiryaev [18] and Asmussen and Taksar [2], dividend optimisation was considered. In other papers (see Browne [3], [4] and Højgaard and Taksar [14]) only risk was controlled, with the dividend distribution scheme being exogenously fixed or with criteria related to other than dividends optimization. The most typical example of a financial corporation in this type of problems is an insurance company. By and large the risk control within an insurance company is maintained by a process called reinsurance. The reinsurance company receives from the primary insurance carrier (the cedent) a certain part of all premiums. In return it is obliged to pay a certain part of each claim according to an a priori established rule. In this paper we will treat one of the most common in the reinsurance industry cases of the excess-of-loss reinsurance. Within this scheme the cedent pays all of the claim up to a fixed amount a (the retention level), while all in excess of a is paid by the reinsurance company. The problem, which is faced by the cedent is how to chose dynamically in an optimal way the retention level a and the dividend distribution policy.

Let r(t) be the reserve of an insurance company at time t. Assume that the cumulative amount of dividends paid out by the company up to time t is L(t). Also at each time t the company applies some dynamic reinsurance rule governed by a parameter a(t). If c is the discount factor then how should the company choose L(t) and a(t) in order to maximize the total expected discounted value of all dividends ever paid out? That is, to maximize E τ 0 e -ct dL(t) (here τ ≤ ∞ is the ruin time). The case of proportional reinsurance arrangement where the retention level a(t) ∈ [0, 1] is the fraction of each claim carried by the cedent has been studied by Højgaard and Taksar [14], [15], [16] (for the simpler case of no reinsurance, see Asmussen and Taksar [2] and Jeanblanc-Pique and Shiryaev [18] and references there within). One of the objectives of our studies in this paper is to compare the proportional reinsurance and the excess-of-loss reinsurance: which arrangement is more profitable? Our mathematical results and numerical examples will be formulated within the framework of controlled diffusion models, see e.g. Fleming and Rishel [6]. However, for the purpose of motivation it is convenient to start from the classical Cramér-Lundberg model. In this model we have without reinsurance and dividend payments that the reserve of the company is given by R t = R 0 + pt -Nt process with intensity β representing the arrival times of the claims and the U i (the claim sizes) are i.i.d. with common distribution F having finite first and second moments µ ∞ , σ 2 ∞ (the use of this notation will later become clear). The objective is to find an optimal policy π * such that V (x ) = V π * (x ) for all x .

In the case of proportional reinsurance an explicit solution to this problem was found by Højgaard and Taksar [16]. A comparison of (1.5) and (1.8) indicates, however, that from the mathematical point of view the excess-of-loss reinsurance is a harder problem than proportional reinsurance: the functional relation between µ(a) and σ 2 (a) is much more complicated in (1.8) than in (1.5) even for a relatively simple densities f such as the exponential. Accordingly, the solution we provide for the excess-of-loss reinsurance is less explicit than in [16], nevertheless it is computationally tractable. We will see that the problem can be reduced to the solution of a free boundary problem to an ordinary differential equation, which in turn can be reduced to an ordinary differential equation with boundary conditions determined by the solution to a set of transcendental equations.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, we consider the reparametrization of the problem obtained by taking µ (the drift term) as the basic control parameter. This is inspired by Radner and Shepp [21] and is a key idea for the mathematical analysis. In Sect. 3, we prove that the excess-of-loss reinsurance is always better than the proportional one. Though simple to establish, this result is of a great practical interest. In Sect. 4 we prove that the optimal return function is always a concave function, which is essential for solving the optimization problem. Section 5 and 6 contain the derivation of the optimal excess-of-loss reinsurance policy π * in the case of unrestricted and restricted rates of dividend payments respectively. Here we need to distinguish between the situations of the distribution F having finite or infinite support. Section 7 is devoted to numerical examples, including numerical comparisons between the excess-of-loss reinsurance and the proportional one in different cases and Sect. 8 contains some closing remarks.

div.head: The optimal policy
div.p: To complete the solution of the optimal control problem we need to construct the optimal policy. This is a rather standard procedure (see e.g., Højgaard and Taksar [16] for details). In the case of the unbounded support, the optimal feedback action a * (x ) is determined via (5.3), namely

for x ≤ x 1 and a * (x ) = ∞ for x > x 1 . In the case of bounded support, a * (x ) is determined by (5.35) for x ≤ x 0 , while a * (x ) = N for x > x 0 . The optimal reserve process r * (t) is a diffusion process with drift u(x ) and diffusion σ(x ), with reflection at x 1 and absorption at 0. The optimal dividend pay-out L * (t) is the functional which causes the unreflected diffusion process to be reflected at the boundary x 1 . In terms of r * (t), the functional L is the local time of r * a the point x 1 .

At a more heuristic level, our optimal policy is the following. The retention level depends on the current reserve x and is equal to a * (x ). The dividend policy consists of paying out all the money in excess of x 1 , so that under the optimal policy the reserve never exceeds that level.

div.head: The optimal policy
div.p: If F has infinite support the retention level depends on the current reserve x and is equal to a * (x ) for x < x 1 and equal to a * (x 1 ) for x > x 1 . The dividend policy consists of paying out dividend at maximum rate M if the reserve exceeds x 1 .

If F has finite support, then we may reach maximum retention level N at some point x 0 ≤ x 1 if M is sufficiently large. For small M we will reach a constant level of retention at x 1 which is less than maximum.

These are compared to the optimal return functions using proportional reinsurance (from Højgaard and Taksar [16]) and using no reinsurance (from Asmussen and Taksar [2]). div.p: In this section we consider the case of unbounded rate of dividend and make calculations for different choices of discount rate c. Not surprisingly we see that differences between the three choices of reinsurance decreases as c increases.

div.head: Bounded rate of dividend
div.p: In this case we fix the discount rate c = 0.1 and consider different cases of maximum rate of dividend pay-out M . Remark 7.1 Obviously the gain of choosing excess-of-loss reinsurance in the exponential case is larger than in the uniform case. This has a simple explanation. The reason for reinsurance is to lower the risk and as mentioned in Højgaard and Taksar [16] a good measure of risk is σ 2 ∞ /µ ∞ . In the exponential case this equals 2 and in the uniform case it is 2/3. Excess-of-loss reinsurance is more efficient for risk avoidance and since the risk is larger in the exponential case, this efficiency becomes more clear in this case.

div.head: The probability of ruin
div.p: From Karlin and Taylor [19, p. 228] we know that the ruin probability under the optimal policy P(τ * < ∞) = 0 if We have argued that W (z ) ∼ z -1/(1+2c) and if we at least choose c < 1/2 we have S (x ) = ∞. This means that in the case of unrestricted rate of dividend, even though paying out dividends reflects the risk process at x 1 the presence of reinsurance prevents ruin. This is also the case with proportional reinsurance, see Højgaard and Taksar [16], whereas in the absence of reinsurance, as treated in Asmussen and Taksar [2], P(τ * < ∞) = 1.

div.head: Optimality of excess-of-loss reinsurance?
div.p: The result of Theorem 3.1, which states that you can always find an excess-ofloss reinsurance policy, which is better than proportional reinsurance policies, agrees with the result of Gerber [8], which states that in the compound Poisson model with premium calculated by means of the expected value principle excess-of-loss reinsurance is the reinsurance form that maximizes the adjustment coefficient for the cedent. It can be shown, that this is not the case for other types of premium principles (see e.g. Hesselager [13]), therefore a topic for further work would be to consider other premium principles. In general this is a complicated matter, but one example is trivial. Assume we use the variance principle (with cheap reinsurance), i.e. In this case our control parameter is the drift term µ(x ) = σ 2 (x ) and it is easily seen that the optimal choice is µ(x ) = µ ∞ , which correspond to no reinsurance at all and you get the solution of Asmussen and Taksar [2] with µ = σ 2 . This has an straightforward explanation: No matter which reinsurance form and which retention level one chooses, the measure of risk σ 2 (x )/µ(x ) = 1, so one might as well take full risk.
